body.p:
Kentucky Governor and attorney. Elizabethtown native. Married to Lucinda Hardin Helm.
Father of Benjamin Hardin Helm, George H. Helm, Elizabeth B. Helm, Rebecca J. Helm, Lucinda B. Helm, Sarah Helm, Emily Helm, Mary Helm, John L. Helm, James P. Helm, and Thomas Helm. Enslaved 52 people 1860. Studied under Benjamin Tobin and admitted to the bar in 1823. Served as Meade County Attorney from 1824-1840. Elected to Kentucky House of Representatives in 1825, 1827, 1830, 1833 to 1837, 1839, 1842, 1843, and in which he also served as speaker in the 1835, 1836, 1839, 1842, and 1843 sessions. Served as a member of the Kentucky State Senate from 1844 to 1848, and was elected on the Whig ticket as lieutenant governor of Kentucky, a position he held from 1848 to 1850, assuming governorship in 1850 upon John Crittenden's resignation. President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad from 1854 to 1860.
